source.d10285b2:
projectID <- “my_GCP_project”

sql <-	"SELECT  provider_id, provider_name, provider_city, provider_state, provider_zipcode 
FROM `bigquery-public-data.cms_medicare.inpatient_charges_2011`”

#execute sql query to pull data from Google cloud
inp_chg <- query_exec(sql, project = projectID, use_legacy_sql = F, max_pages = Inf)

source.559246bf: # How to Query the Medicare Dataset using R
source.259e3dd4: Once the library is installed, run the following command to import the library:
source.2ae98424:
This blog post is based on the article “[Google Cloud Platform for Data Scientists: Using R with Google BigQuery](https://cloud.google.com/blog/products/gcp/google-cloud-platform-for-data-scientists-using-r-with-google-bigquery)” by Gus Glass in Google Cloud Product News.

First thing first, the cost of using BigQuery for this particular datasets is $0 since [the service is free for query processes under 1TB](https://cloud.google.com/bigquery/docs/estimate-costs) (the largest data is 3.17 GB). You will need to set up a [Cloud platform project](https://cloud.google.com/dataproc/docs/guides/setup-project) and enable billing. The project ID will be used later in R to point to this project.

To access BigQuery using R, we will use the library “bigquery” created by Hadley Wickham. To install the library, run the following command in R:
